name.text: Domain and Range of a Function

questiontext.text:
We define the real-valued function \( f(x)={@fx@} \)

Determine the domain and the range of \(f\), as subsets of the real numbers represented by inequalities.
Also write these sets as intervals of the real numbers.

Note: To enter intervals of you real line, you should write the relevant text in the table below.

Intervals Input Syntax
\( [a,b] \) cc(a,b)
\( (a,b) \) oo(a,b)
\( [a,b) \) co(a,b)
\( (a,b] \) oc(a,b)
\( (a, \infty) \) oo(a,inf)
\( (-\infty, b] \) oc(-inf,b)
\( (-\infty, \infty) \) oo(-inf,inf)

(a) \(Dom(f) = \{ x \in \mathbb{R} : \) [[input:ans1]] [[validation:ans1]] \(\leq x \leq\) [[input:ans2]] [[validation:ans2]] \(\}\) = [[input:ans5]] [[validation:ans5]]

[[feedback:prt1]]

(b) \(Range(f) = \{ y \in \mathbb{R} : \) [[input:ans3]] [[validation:ans3]] \(\leq x \leq\) [[input:ans4]] [[validation:ans4]] \(\}\) = [[input:ans6]] [[validation:ans6]]

[[feedback:prt2]]

generalfeedback.text:
Worked Solution

(a) Since we require \(f\) to be real-valued, to determine the domain of \(f(x)\) we need to find the values of \(x\) for which \({@bb^2 - x^2@} \geq 0\).

To do this, we first find the roots of the quadratic. In this case,

\({@bb^2-x^2@} = {@(bb-x)*(bb+x)@}\)

So, the roots are \(x = {@-bb@}\) and \(x = {@bb@}\).

Now, since the coefficient of the \(x^2\) term is negative, the values between the roots will be positive.
In particular, we can verify that for \(x = 0\),

\({@bb^2-x^2@} = {@bb^2@} > 0\)

Hence, the domain of \(f\) is the set \( \{ x \in \mathbb{R} : {@-bb@} \leq x \leq {@bb@} \}={@ta5@} \)


(b) To determine the range of \(f\), we need to find the minimal and maximal values of the function. Since \(f\) is continuous it must take every value between its minimum and maximum, so these values will give us the range.

To determine the minimum we have, by definition, that the square root function is non-negative. So,

\(f(x) \geq 0\).

To see that \(f\) does actually attain the value \(0\), we note that \(f({@bb@}) = 0\).


To determine the maximum, we note that the square root function is increasing, so \(f\) is maximised at the maximum of \({@bb^2@} - x^2\).

Since \(x^2 \geq 0\), we have,

\(\begin{align*} & {@bb^2@} - x^2 \leq {@bb^2@} \\ &\Rightarrow f(x) = {@fx@} \leq {@bb@} \end{align*}\)

To see that \(f\) does actually attain the value \({@bb@}\), we note that \(f(0) = {@bb@}\).


Hence, we have noted that \(0 \leq f(x) \leq {@bb@}\) and \(f\) attains the values of \(0\) and {@bb@}.

Therefore, the range of \(f\) is the set \( \{ y \in \mathbb{R} : 0 \leq y \leq {@bb@} \}={@ta6@} \)

questionnote.text:
\(f(x) = {@fx@}\)

\( Dom(f)=\{ x \in \mathbb{R} : {@-bb@} \leq x \leq {@bb@} \}={@ta5@} \)

\( Range(f)=\{ y \in \mathbb{R} : 0 \leq y \leq {@bb@} \}={@ta6@} \)

prtcorrect.text: Correct answer, well done.

prtpartiallycorrect.text: Your answer is partially correct.

prtincorrect.text: Incorrect answer.

falsefeedback.text:
The inequality you have given does not contain any values for \(x\) since the lower bound is greater than the upper bound.
Your answer is equivalent to the claim \(Dom(f) = \emptyset\), which is not true since there are real \(x\) for which we can evaluate \(f(x)\).

truefeedback.text:
The domain you have given contains values of \(x\) for which we cannot evaluate \(f\).
For example, \({@if ans1

falsefeedback.text:
The inequality that you have given, \( {@ans1@} \leq x \leq {@ans2@} \), is correct.
However, you have not expressed this inequality with the correct real interval.

Remember that non-strict inequalities are represented using square brackets around the upper and lower bounds of the inequality. So,

\( \{ x \in \mathbb{R} : {@-bb@} \leq x \leq {@bb@} \} = {@ta5@}\)

The inequality you have given does not contain any values for \(y\) since the lower bound is greater than the upper bound.
Your answer is equivalent to the claim \(Range(f) = \emptyset\), which is not true since \(f(x)\) evaluates to a real value for some values of \(x\).

", "

This is impossible since the square-root function is positive by definition.", "
Therefore, \\(", counter_ex3, " \\notin Range(f)\\).

\\(\\begin{align*} &f(x) = ", counter_ex3, " \\\\ &\\Rightarrow \\sqrt{", bb^2 - x^2, "} = ", counter_ex3, " \\\\ &\\Rightarrow ", bb^2 - x^2, " = ", counter_ex3^2, " \\\\ &\\Rightarrow ", x^2, " = ", bb^2 - counter_ex3^2, " < 0 \\end{align*}\\)

", "

This is impossible since \\(x \\in \\mathbb{R}\\) so \\(x^2 \\geq 0\\).", "
Therefore, \\(", counter_ex3, " \\notin Range(f)\\).

falsefeedback.text:
The inequality that you have given, \( {@ans3@} \leq y \leq {@ans4@} \), is correct.
However, you have not expressed this inequality with the correct real interval.

Remember that non-strict inequalities are represented using square brackets around the upper and lower bounds of the inequality.
So,

\( \{ x \in \mathbb{R} : 0 \leq x \leq {@bb@} \} = {@ta6@} \)
